description: False negatives from experiment_7 - LLM decisions only (excludes retrieval failures)

DCF-32.control_description: Company policies are accessible to all employees and, as applicable, third parties such as contractors. Personnel are required to acknowledge the information security policy and other topic-specific policies based on their job duties during onboarding and annually thereafter.

llm_decision.evidence_quote: Employees, contractors and third party users must agree and sign the terms and conditions of their employment contract, and comply with acceptable use.

gaps_identified.description: The policy mandates acknowledgement during onboarding but fails to require annual re-acknowledgement thereafter.

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial. The policy mandates that all personnel sign and comply with the policy during onboarding, but it lacks the required mandate for annual re-acknowledgement.

llm_decision.evidence_quote: Once each year, as a condition of your employment, you’re required to acknowledge that you have received the Code of Conduct and understand its rules.
llm_decision.location_reference: Page 6, Your Annual Acknowledgment of the Code of Conduct

gaps_identified.description: The mandatory acknowledgment process is specifically defined for the Code of Conduct, but is not explicitly required for the dedicated Information Security Policy artifact.

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial. scope_gap: While the policy establishes a perfect mechanism for onboarding and annual acknowledgment, it applies to the Code of Conduct rather than the formal Information Security Policy required by the control (G-15).
No match. G-10: While the policy is available (page 1) and training is required annually (page 3), it does not mandate the specific 'acknowledgment' action required by the control.

llm_decision.evidence_quote: The security policy will define information security roles and responsibilities for all personnel, and all personnel will be made aware of and acknowledge their information security responsibilities.

gaps_identified.description: Policy mandates acknowledgment but does not specify the required frequency (onboarding and annually thereafter).

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial. Mandate for acknowledgment exists, but the specific temporal requirements (onboarding and annual) are absent.
No match. G-10: Policy mandates accessibility ('readily available') but lacks mandatory qualifiers for personnel acknowledgement during onboarding and annually thereafter.

DCF-385.control_description: Media with sensitive data transported within or outside the company's facilities is logged, securely transported (e.g., via secure courier or other trackable method), and captured within tracking logs to include details about media location, responsible party, etc.

llm_decision.evidence_quote: Authorization will be required for removing media from [COMPANY NAME] facilities or assets, when necessary and practical.

gaps_identified.description: Policy mandates authorization and audit logs (tracking) for media removal, but fails to mandate secure transportation methods (e.g., secure courier) as required by the control.

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial. The policy mandates logging and tracking (audit trails) for media removal from facilities but lacks the requirement for 'secure transport' mechanisms during the transit phase (G-10).

llm_decision.evidence_quote: Media with sensitive data sent outside the company's facilities will be logged, securely transmitted (e.g., via secure courier or other trackable method), and captured within offsite tracking logs to include details about media location.

gaps_identified.description: Policy mandate only applies to media sent outside facilities, whereas the control requires coverage for both internal and external transport.

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial. scope_gap: Policy mandates secure transport and logging only for media sent outside company facilities.

DCF-76.control_description: Emergency changes or hot fixes implemented outside of the standard change management process are reviewed and approved by an authorized individual after implementation.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-9: The policy describes expedited processes for emergency changes but does not mandate a post-implementation review and approval by an authorized individual.
No match. G-12: The policy provides an external reference to a 'change control standard' but does not explicitly mandate post-implementation review and approval for emergency changes.

DCF-681.control_description: The Organization conducts periodic phishing simulations or social engineering tests as part of the company's security awareness initiatives.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Phishing simulations are listed as an example ('such as') within the training section (page 4), and example text is automatically rejected as binding evidence for a mandate.
No match. G-10: Phishing simulations are listed only as an example ('e.g.') of a delivery method for training, not as a mandatory requirement.

DCF-368.control_name: Restricted Physical Access to Publicly Accessible Network Jacks
DCF-368.control_description: The Organization has implemented physical and/or logical controls to restrict access to publicly accessible network jacks.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: The policy mandates restricting access to network equipment and public areas but does not explicitly address the required qualifier of network jacks.
No match. G-4: Policy mandates general cabling protection and area security but does not explicitly target the restriction of access to network jacks.

DCF-802.control_description: The Organization has mechanisms and procedures in place to collect input from internal and external stakeholders regarding AI systems, their operations, and their impact.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-17: The policy describes review inputs and communication lines but lacks a mandate to establish a specific feedback collection mechanism for internal and external stakeholders. Relevant sections in Appendix A are part of an optional template.

DCF-803.control_description: The Organization has mechanisms in place to allow individuals or groups to opt out of or contest problematic AI system outcomes.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-3: The policy mandates a process for 'reporting concerns' (Control A.3.3), but this is a detection/reporting mechanism and does not satisfy the requirement for an opt-out or contestation mechanism.

DCF-812.control_description: The Organization assesses and documents consideration for environmental impact related to AI systems.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-13: Section 4.1 identifies climate change as a relevant issue to the AIMS context, but the document lacks a binding mandate (must/shall) to assess and document these impacts, instead listing them as something that 'could be monitored' (Section 9.1).

DCF-811.control_name: AI System Fairness and Bias Evaluation
DCF-811.control_description: The Organization has documented and implemented processes to evaluate fairness and bias in AI systems.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-4: The policy mandates 'impact assessments' for individuals and society (Section 6.1.4), which is a related but distinct governance activity from the specific evaluation of fairness and bias.

DCF-886.control_name: DHCP Logging and IP Address Management
DCF-886.control_description: The Organization has enabled DHCP logging on all DHCP servers and/or utilizes an Internet Protocol (IP) Address Management (IPAM) tool to track and update the enterprise’s asset inventory. Logs generated by these systems are reviewed and used to update the asset inventory at least weekly, or more frequently as necessary, to ensure accurate asset visibility and compliance with security policies.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Missing mandatory qualifiers (DHCP logging, IPAM tool usage, and weekly review frequency).

DCF-888.control_description: Any unauthorized software without documented exceptions shall either be removed from use on enterprise assets or receive a documented exception.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-17: The policy describes what the inventory process 'will facilitate' (utility) rather than establishing a binding mandate that unauthorized software must be removed or assigned exceptions.

DCF-889.control_name: Automated Software Inventory Tool is Utilized
DCF-889.control_description: The Organization utilize software inventory tools, when possible, throughout the enterprise to automate the discovery and documentation of installed software.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-16: The policy describes the use of an automated system for infrastructure assets, but does not mandate an automated tool for the discovery and documentation of 'installed software'.

DCF-149.control_description: The Organization encrypts removable media devices, such as USB drives, digital video disks, compact disks, external or removable hard disks, etc., that contain sensitive data, to protect the confidentiality of the information during transport.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: The policy statement regarding cryptography for removable media (Page 6) uses non-binding 'should' language, failing the requirement for a mandate.

DCF-785.control_description: The Organization maintains secure and supported configuration standards and versions for system components and replaces those components when support is no longer available from the developer, vendor, or manufacturer. Where unsupported components cannot be replaced, The Organization identifies and documents risk mitigation strategies.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Missing mandatory qualifier for risk mitigation strategies for unsupported components. G-17: Tracking replacement is an input/artifact of the lifecycle but does not satisfy the replacement mandate itself.

DCF-885.control_description: The Organization has implemented and configured an active discovery tool to identify assets connected to the enterprise network; the tool is configured to run on at least a daily basis to ensure continuous asset discovery and visibility.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: While the policy specifies the use of automated tools (Drata) for asset discovery, it lacks the mandatory numeric qualifier for 'daily' frequency.

DCF-892.control_description: Configure trusted DNS servers on network infrastructure. Example implementations include configuring network devices to use enterprise-controlled DNS servers and/or reputable externally accessible DNS servers.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. No mention of DNS server configurations or trusted DNS mandates found in the document.

DCF-267.control_name: Sensitive Data on Removable Media Encrypted
DCF-267.control_description: Sensitive data on removable storage media is encrypted wherever stored.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Evidence uses non-binding language ('should be used') for the core mechanism, failing to provide a mandate.

DCF-788.control_description: The Organization maintains a documented inventory of all system components, products, or services that store or process controlled unclassified information (CUI) to facilitate data discovery efforts. The inventory includes information about the type of data, the system where the data is stored or processed, the data elements (metadata), access controls, and other attributes deemed relevant by the organization. The inventory is reviewed and updated when there are changes in the location of CUI.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: The policy requires an inventory of sensitive information (PHI, personal data), but does not explicitly address the specific regulatory category of Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI).

DCF-923.control_description: The Organization maintains a list of new assets and facilities. Management formally authorizes the use of all new assets prior to their operation, and the authorization is updated periodically. Documentation of management authorization is retained.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Policy mandates an asset list and owner assignment but lacks the requirement for formal management authorization prior to operation.

DCF-574.control_description: A mobile device management (MDM) is installed in company-issued devices and bring-your-own devices used for company purposes to enforce security for assets off-premise (e.g., location tracking, remote locking and wiping, threat detection, restrictions on software installation, etc.)

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-1/G-2: The policy describes a manual data wipe process performed by an IT manager rather than the automated technical enforcement (remote locking/wiping via MDM) required by the control.

DCF-622.control_description: The Organization manages the physical access control for output devices.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-1: The policy includes printers in the inventory (page 2) and mandates general access restrictions based on classification (page 1), but lacks a specific mandate for physical access control of output devices.

DCF-920.control_description: The Organization maintains a list of all personnel (employees and contractors) and third-party users.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-4: Topic mismatch; tracking 'user accounts' in a digital inventory is not equivalent to maintaining a comprehensive personnel list of all employees and contractors.

DCF-887.control_name: Passive Network Discovery for Asset Inventory Management
DCF-887.control_description: The Organization utilizes a passive discovery tool to continuously identify assets connected to the enterprise network, scan results are reviewed and used to update the enterprise asset inventory at least weekly, or more frequently as necessary.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-4: The policy describes automated cloud infrastructure querying (Drata), which is not network-layer passive discovery. G-10: Missing the required weekly frequency qualifier.

DCF-821.control_description: The Organization assigns identifiable owners (e.g., individuals, organizations, or projects) to removable system media used in the organization. The Organization prohibits the use of removable system media when such devices have no identifiable owner.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. The policy requires authorization and records for media removal but fails to explicitly mandate the assignment of identifiable owners to media or prohibit the use of unowned media.

DCF-77.control_description: Backups of production data are performed at least daily and are configured to be retained in accordance with the retention periods established in company policies and procedures.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: The policy uses placeholders (<BACKUP FREQUENCY>) for backup intervals and does not mandate the 'at least daily' requirement.

DCF-193.control_description: The Organization information security policies should be augmented by a statement concerning support for and commitment to achieving compliance with applicable PII protection legislation and the contractual terms agreed between the public cloud PII processor and its clients (cloud service customers).

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-15: This is a standalone Breach Notification Policy, not an Information Security Policy augmented by cloud-specific PII processor terms.

DCF-983.control_description: The Organization has disabled or removed older versions of Powershell 2.0 that are no longer supported by Microsoft (e.g., version 2.0 for Windows 10 and 11).

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. PowerShell is not mentioned in the policy document.

DCF-969.control_description: The Organization ensures that application control is implemented on non-internet-facing servers, and restricts the execution of drivers to an organization-approved set.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: While the policy mandates approved executable code (Page 3), it lacks the mandatory qualifiers to restrict drivers or specify non-internet-facing servers.

DCF-968.control_description: The Organization ensures that application control is implemented on internet-facing servers, and is applied to all locations other than user profiles and temporary folders used by operating systems, web browsers and email clients.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Policy requirement for approved executable code (Page 3) lacks the mandatory qualifiers for internet-facing servers and specific folder exclusions.

DCF-967.control_description: The Organization ensures that application control is implemented on workstations, and applied to user profiles and temporary folders used by operating systems, web browsers and email clients.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-5/G-10: Evidence targets 'operational systems' (production) rather than 'workstations', and lacks the required qualifiers regarding user profiles and temporary folders.

DCF-105.control_description: Personnel, including employees and contractors, are required to sign an agreement that outlines confidentiality requirements (e.g., non-disclosure agreements) prior to hire.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-8: Timing mismatch; control requires signing prior to hire, while policy (Page 6) mandates acknowledgment only when employees 'start'. G-15: The policy mandates acknowledging the Code of Conduct, not a specific Non-Disclosure Agreement artifact.

DCF-528.control_description: The Organization maintains policies and procedures to properly identify, label and store sensitive information (e.g., PII, PHI, Cardholder Data, etc.), and to manage and document the use, transfer, storage, and disposal of physical media containing sensitive information. Personnel are trained and made aware of how to handle sensitive information and report related incidents.

llm_decision.evidence_quote: Must be destroyed when no longer needed.

gaps_identified.description: The policy lacks an explicit mandate for personnel training and awareness regarding information handling.

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial. G-17: While the policy covers labeling, storage, disposal, and incident reporting, it does not mandate the training/awareness program required by the control.

DCF-381.control_description: Media with sensitive data is physically secured to prevent unauthorized persons from gaining access to it.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-8: Evidence for physical security is limited to specific lifecycle phases (destruction and transport) rather than a general mandate for media at rest.

DCF-386.control_description: Management approves all assets (including media with sensitive data) that are moved within or outside the facility, including when the assets are distributed to individuals. Documentation of management's approval for the movement of assets is retained.

llm_decision.evidence_quote: Management will approve all media with sensitive data that is moved outside the facility (including when media is distributed to individuals).

gaps_identified.description: Policy only covers media moved outside the facility, whereas control requires approval for movement both within and outside.

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial. scope_gap: The mandate is limited to movement outside the facility and only covers sensitive media, not all assets as required by the control.

DCF-108.control_description: The Organization uses secure storage mechanisms for digital media and hardcopy materials that contain sensitive data (e.g., locked codes, combination locks to offices, rooms and facilities such as key cabinets, etc.) as well as critical equipment and other assets. Access to the secured storage mechanisms (including access to physical keys and knowledge of authentication information) is restricted to authorized personnel.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-5: Policy only mandates secure storage containers for hard-copy materials awaiting destruction; it does not mandate secure storage (locks/cabinets) for all active media or critical equipment.

DCF-590.control_description: The Organization uses automated tools to facilitate information sharing decisions by authorized users.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-1: The policy describes Data Leakage Prevention for blocking transfers and Information Exchange agreements, not automated tools for facilitating sharing decisions.

DCF-595.control_description: The Organization defines actions to be covered by non-repudiation and maintains records of the actions performed.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-11: Policy mandates detailed audit logging but does not explicitly define or mandate non-repudiation actions as a distinct control objective.

DCF-3.control_description: Administrator access to web-based management interfaces is encrypted with strong cryptographic algorithms.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-14: General encryption requirements for 'all internet and intranet connections' do not constitute a specific mandate for the protection of 'web-based management interfaces'.

DCF-596.control_description: The Organization only allows authorized personnel to modify log settings/configurations.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. No binding mandate found restricting the ability to modify log settings or configurations to authorized personnel.

DCF-150.control_description: The Organization has implemented data leakage prevention mechanisms to systems that could process, store or transmit sensitive information (e.g., sending personal information via email). These mechanisms are configured to prevent data leakage and generate audit logs and alerts.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Evidence uses future-tense language ('will implement') which acts as an aspirational promise rather than a binding mandate that the control is currently in place.

DCF-775.control_description: The Organization has enabled deletion protection for cloud resources to prevent irreversible data loss or downtime resulting from accidental or malicious actions.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Policy describes deletion methods but does not mandate the specific technical qualifier of 'deletion protection' for cloud resources.

DCF-52.control_description: Hard-disk encryption is enabled on all company-managed devices.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-5: Policy scope is limited to Production Systems; it does not mandate full-disk encryption for all company-managed devices (e.g., end-user laptops).

DCF-782.control_description: The Organization has configured lifecycle rules for cloud storage to delete data automatically after expiration of their retention periods.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-16: Policy mandates data removal after a period but does not require the technical configuration of automated cloud storage lifecycle rules.

DCF-26.control_description: The Organization conducts tests of the business continuity/disaster recovery plans at least annually. Results and lessons learned are documented, and updates to the plans are made as necessary.

llm_decision.evidence_quote: The Security Officer shall establish criteria for validation/testing of a Disaster Recovery Plan, an annual test schedule, and ensure implementation of the test.

gaps_identified.description: The policy mandates annual testing but fails to require the documentation of results, lessons learned, or the subsequent update of the plans.

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial. scope_gap: The core mandate for annual testing is clearly defined, but the secondary requirements for documenting results and updating the plan are missing.

DCF-645.control_description: The Organization ensures that communication at the session level is protected.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-14: The policy mentions specific tools (SSL/VPN) but does not mandate the broad protection of all communication at the session level.

DCF-284.control_description: The Organization has implemented security mechanisms so that only trusted keys and/or certificates are accepted during transmission of sensitive data that are confirmed valid and not expired or revoked.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-1: The control requires a technical mechanism for validation and rejection during transmission; the policy only describes administrative lifecycle processes for replacing expired keys (Page 3).

DCF-54.control_description: Data at rest is encrypted using strong cryptographic algorithms.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: The policy lacks a general mandate for 'data at rest' encryption; the only mention of 'at rest' (Page 5) is a review criterion for cloud providers.

DCF-912.control_description: The Organization employs cryptographic modules that are certified and that adhere to the minimum applicable standards when used to protect the confidentiality of information.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: The control requires 'certified' cryptographic modules; the policy only mandates 'approved' tools and 'conformance to standards' without a certification requirement.

DCF-937.control_name: Authentication of Non-user Accounts and Services
DCF-937.control_description: The Organization ensures that non-user accounts and services are authenticated through appropriate and secure methods.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-4: The policy defines requirements for PKI and SSL certificates but does not address the authentication of non-user accounts and services.

DCF-609.control_description: The Organization has an established process for public key authentication for individuals, machines, and devices.

llm_decision.evidence_quote: [COMPANY NAME] must protect individual systems or information by means of cryptographic controls as defined in Table 3:

gaps_identified.description: The policy mandates PKI for authentication and details processes for individuals (smart cards), but lacks procedural details for machines and devices.

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial. Mandate for PKI authentication exists via Table 3 and applies to all systems via IR-1, but the established process is only detailed for individual end-users.

DCF-767.control_name: Incident Procedures When Unauthorized PII Detected
DCF-767.control_description: The Organization documented incident response procedures include processes to respond, analyze, and address situations in the event that PII is detected where it is not authorized (e.g., system logs, etc.)

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-4: Topic overlaps but differs; control requires procedures for PII detected in unauthorized locations (e.g. sanitization), while policy addresses response to a PII breach.

DCF-499.control_description: The Organization's incident response plan includes roles, responsibilities, and communication and contact strategies in the event of a suspected or confirmed security incident (including notification of payment brands and acquirers), incident response procedures with specific containment and mitigation activities for different types of incidents, business recovery and continuity procedures, data backup processes, analysis of legal requirements for reporting compromises, coverage and responses of all critical system components, and reference or inclusion of incident response procedures from the payment brands.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Missing multiple required PCI qualifiers including notification of payment brands, data backup processes, and inclusion of payment brand procedures.

DCF-871.control_description: The Organization has a designated individual responsible for implementing and executing the company's communication strategy, to include public and media communications, and incident reporting.

llm_decision.evidence_quote: All users must report any system vulnerability, incident, or event pointing to a possible incident to the Security Officer as quickly as possible but no later than 24 hours.

gaps_identified.description: The policy designates a Security Officer for incident reporting but does not assign responsibility for public/media communications or the overall communication strategy.

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial. [scope_gap]: The mandate covers the incident reporting portion of the role, but lacks the public/media and strategic components required by the control.

DCF-34.control_description: The Organization has an assigned security team that is responsible for the design, implementation, management, and review of the organization's security policies, standards, baselines, procedures, and guidelines.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-17: The document assigns an ISM specifically for managing incident response procedures, which is an input/component, not the broad security team responsible for all security policies and standards.

DCF-179.control_description: The Organization has identified and documented skill and competence requirements for personnel that contribute to the development, implementation and oversight of its management system(s) and retains documented evidence of competence.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-11: The policy mentions a 'Skills Matrix' as an example and describes general hiring checks, but does not mandate the identification of competence requirements or retention of evidence for management system personnel.

DCF-746.control_description: The Organization has established training programs to help personnel understand their obligations and responsibilities for the protection of personally identifiable information (PII) and associated regulatory requirements. Personnel (including employees and contractors as applicable) are required to complete the training during onboarding and annually thereafter.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: The policy does not explicitly mandate training for the protection of 'personally identifiable information (PII)' or associated regulatory requirements.

DCF-914.control_description: The Organization maintains a list of new hires (employees and contractors) for the past 12 months.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-11: Policy mandates retention of training and background check records (activities), but not the specific artifact 'list of new hires'.

DCF-171.control_description: The Organization maintains documented procedures that describe how to perform activities including controls, methods, and processes to be followed to achieve the company's policies objectives and compliance activities. The procedures are reviewed and updated as needed to address changes in processes, technologies, and business objectives, or at least annually, and are available to all relevant parties.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-17: The policy mentions accessibility of 'policies and/or procedures' but does not mandate the creation, maintenance, or annual review of operating procedures specifically.

DCF-827.control_description: The role-based security training program and its contents are reviewed and updated at periodic intervals and after any events deemed significant by the organization (e.g., responses to actual incidents, assessment findings, changes in regulatory requirements, introduction of new tools, technologies, or processes, etc.).

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-17: Policy mandates general policy review but lacks a specific mandate for periodic review and updating of role-based training program contents.

DCF-685.control_description: The security awareness program is reviewed at least annually and updated as needed to address any new threats and vulnerabilities that may impact the security of the company's environment or the information provided to personnel about their role in protecting sensitive data.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-17: The policy mandates an annual review of 'security policies' (page 3), but it does not mandate a formal review and update of the 'security awareness program' or its content.

DCF-921.control_description: The Organization provides specialized information security training to executives with significant security responsibilities (e.g., system administrators). Training is provided prior to granting access to systems or sensitive data or performing assigned duties, when required by system changes or defined events, and at periodic intervals.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: The policy lacks the mandatory qualifier for 'senior executive' or 'specialized' training for those with significant security responsibilities; general role-based training mentioned on page 4 is too broad.

DCF-47.control_description: The Organization has documented job descriptions for each position at the company, which include roles and responsibilities as well as required qualifications, skills, and experience for the role.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-11: Policy mentions briefing personnel on roles but does not mandate the creation or maintenance of documented job descriptions for all positions.

DCF-922.control_description: The Organization reviews examine its requirements for confidentiality and non-disclosure agreements periodically according to policy, and when changes occur that influence these requirements. The review includes a review of applicable laws and regulations for the jurisdiction to which the agreements apply.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-17: While the policy mandates signing NDAs (Page 7) and annual policy reviews (Page 3), it does not explicitly mandate a periodic review of the confidentiality/NDA requirements themselves.

DCF-174.control_description: The Organization has a defined policy that establishes requirements and responsibilities for remote work and the use of company and personal IT devices.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-15: While the scope includes remote activity, there is no mandate establishing a specific telework or endpoint device policy within this document.

DCF-160.control_description: The Organization uses compliance automation software to identify, select, and continuously monitor internal controls.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-11: Mention of compliance automation (Drata) on page 3 is explicitly limited to policy accessibility, not the monitoring of internal controls.

DCF-90.control_description: Access to the root account in the cloud infrastructure provider is monitored. Login activity for the root account is investigated and validated for appropriateness.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-14: Evidence for administrative log reviews (p. 3) is too general to satisfy the specific investigation/validation requirement for the cloud root account; G-10: 'routine reviews' does not satisfy 'investigated and validated'.

DCF-478.control_description: The Organization has enabled file integrity monitoring or a change-detection mechanism to detect unauthorized modification (including changes, additions, and deletions) of critical system files, configuration files, audit files, or content files to ensure critical data cannot be changed without generating alerts.

llm_decision.evidence_quote: File integrity monitoring or change-detection mechanisms will be used on audit logs to ensure that existing log data cannot be changed without generating alerts.

gaps_identified.description: Policy mandates FIM for audit logs but does not explicitly require it for critical system, configuration, or content files.

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial. scope_gap: The core mechanism (FIM) is mandated but the scope of assets covered is limited to audit logs, excluding other critical files required by the control.

DCF-91.control_description: An intrusion detection system (IDS)/intrusion prevention system (IPS) or equivalent is in place to detect real-time suspicious or anomalous network traffic that may be indicative of threat actor activity and is configured to alert personnel when a potential intrusion is detected.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-1: The policy mandates logging and monitoring of IDS/IPS failures but does not mandate the implementation or configuration of the IDS/IPS itself.

DCF-95.control_description: The Organization monitors processing capacity and use of resources continuously to manage demand and to enable the implementation of additional resources as necessary.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-3: Logging resource exhaustion failures (p2) is a reactive detection mechanism and does not satisfy the requirement for continuous capacity monitoring and demand management.

DCF-698.control_name: Automated Mechanisms for Audit Log Reviews
DCF-698.control_description: The Organization has implemented automated mechanisms for audit record reduction that supports correlated audit log review and analysis, such as centralized log management systems, event log analyzers, security information and event management (SIEM) solutions, etc.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-17: While the policy mentions monitoring 'Audit log review mechanisms' for failure (Page 4), it does not explicitly mandate the implementation or use of SIEM/automated reduction tools for correlated analysis.

DCF-985.control_description: The Organization has enabled PowerShell module logging, script block logging and transcription events.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-16: The policy mandates logging interactive application use generally, but lacks the specific technical configurations for PowerShell module, script block, and transcription logging.

DCF-897.control_name: Enterprise DNS Query Logging and Monitoring
DCF-897.control_description: The Organization collects DNS query audit logs on enterprise assets, where appropriate and supported, to enhance security monitoring and threat detection.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-4: Policy mandates logging failures of DNS services (p. 2), which is distinct from the control requirement to collect DNS query audit logs.

DCF-87.control_description: A threat detection system is in place to monitor web traffic and suspicious activity. When anomalous traffic activity is identified, alerts are automatically sent to personnel, investigated, and escalated through the incident management process, if necessary.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-1: The policy mentions logging events from security tools but does not mandate the implementation of a threat detection system for monitoring web traffic.

DCF-899.control_name: Collection of Command Line Audit Logs
DCF-899.control_description: The Organization collects and retains command-line audit logs from administrative terminals, including but not limited to PowerShell, BASH, and remote administrative sessions.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Policy requires logging administrative actions (p. 2) but lacks the specific technical qualifier for 'command-line' or shell-specific logs.

DCF-900.control_name: Service Provider Log Collection and Monitoring
DCF-900.control_description: The Organization collects and retains service provider logs, where supported, to ensure visibility into authentication and authorization events, data creation and disposal activities, and user management changes.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-13: Policy mandates assessing whether cloud logging is sufficient (p. 2), whereas the control requires the actual collection and retention of those logs.

DCF-896.control_description: The Organization ensures that logging destinations maintain adequate storage.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-16: Policy mandates backing up logs to a central server, but does not mandate the operational requirement to maintain adequate storage capacity at that destination.

DCF-824.control_description: The Organization has implemented mechanisms to monitor remote access sessions on system components (e.g., servers, workstations, notebook computers, smart phones, and tablets).

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-4: Logging network connections (p. 1) overlaps with the topic but does not specifically mandate the mechanism for monitoring remote access sessions.

DCF-614.control_description: The Organization has implemented automated mechanisms and tools to conduct maintenance, repairs, and replacement actions on organizational systems.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-1: Policy mandates administrative approval and monitoring of maintenance tools rather than the implementation of automated mechanisms to conduct maintenance actions.

DCF-21.control_description: A documented architectural diagram is in place to document system boundaries and support the functioning of internal control. The diagram is reviewed and approved by management at least annually and updated as necessary when there are changes to the environment.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-11/G-15: While the policy mandates network and data-flow diagrams, it does not explicitly mandate a formal 'Architectural Diagram' as required by the control.

DCF-73.control_name: Access to Remote Server Administration Ports Restricted
DCF-73.control_description: Network security controls are in place to restrict public access to remote server administration ports (e.g., SSH, RDP) to authorized IP addresses or address ranges only.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-16: Generic traffic restriction exists, but lacks explicit mandate for admin ports (SSH/RDP) or authorized IP address range constraints.

DCF-210.control_name: Insecure Services, Protocols, and Ports Documentation and Control
DCF-210.control_description: The Organization identifies all services, protocols, and ports in use considered to be in use. The Organization identifies, documents and implements security features for each insecure service, protocol, or port in use, such that the risk is mitigated.

llm_decision.evidence_quote: All services, protocols, and ports allowed must be identified, documented, approved, and have a defined business need.

gaps_identified.description: Policy mandates documentation for all services but lacks specific mitigation/security feature requirements for the insecure subset.

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial match. The policy mandates identifying and documenting all allowed ports and protocols, but does not explicitly address risk mitigation for 'insecure' ones.

DCF-231.control_name: Changes in Encryption Keys for Wireless Environments
DCF-231.control_description: For wireless environments connected to the environment or transmitting account data, encryption keys are changed whenever personnel with knowledge of the key leave the company or change roles and whenever a key is suspected of or known to be compromised.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Missing mandatory qualifier linking 'wireless' specific encryption key rotation to the trigger of personnel departure/role change.

DCF-707.control_name: Credentials for System Accounts Not Hard-Coded
DCF-707.control_description: The Organization has implemented mechanisms to validate that authentication credentials for any application and system accounts are not hard coded in scripts, configuration/property files, or bespoke and custom source code.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-16: Control requires 'mechanisms to validate' that credentials are not hard-coded; policy prohibits hard-coding but does not mandate the validation mechanism.

DCF-324.control_description: The Organization evaluates public-facing web applications via manual or automated application vulnerability security assessment tools at least once every 12 months and after significant changes. Vulnerabilities identified, if any, are risk-ranked and corrected, and the application is re-evaluated after the corrections.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Policy lacks the specific 12-month interval and re-evaluation requirements mandated by the control for assessment tools.

DCF-737.control_name: Protected Storage of Secret and Private Keys for Account Data
DCF-737.control_description: Secret and private keys used to encrypt/decrypt stored account data are stored in within a secure cryptographic device (SCD) as at least two full-length key components or key shares in accordance with an industry-accepted method.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Control requires keys be stored in an SCD *as* key shares (compound requirement), while policy lists these as mutually exclusive disjunctive options (OR).

DCF-216.control_name: Network Security Controls Restricting Wireless Network Traffic
DCF-216.control_description: Network security controls are implemented to deny all traffic from wireless networks into the environment by default and only allow wireless traffic with authorized business purpose.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-16: Policy mandates blocking unauthorized traffic (p.3), but lacks the specific 'deny all by default' configuration requirement.

DCF-411.control_name: Audit Trail for Invalid Access Attempts
DCF-411.control_description: Automated audit trails or logs are implemented for all system components to capture all invalid access attempts.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: The policy lists 'success and failure indication' as a detail of events but does not explicitly require 'invalid access attempts' to be captured as an event type.

DCF-412.control_name: Audit Trail for Identification and Authentication Mechanism Changes
DCF-412.control_description: Automated audit trails or logs are implemented to capture all changes to identification and authentication credentials (e.g., creation of new accounts, elevation of privileges, changes, additions, or deletions to accounts with administrative access, etc.).

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: While the policy mandates logging admin actions and user access, it does not explicitly require capturing changes to 'identification and authentication credentials' specifically.

DCF-414.control_name: Audit Trail of System-Level Object Changes
DCF-414.control_description: Automated audit trails or logs are implemented for all system components to capture all creation and deletion of system-level objects.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: The policy does not explicitly require capturing the creation or deletion of system-level objects.

DCF-430.control_description: Audit log files are protected to prevent modifications by individuals (e.g., via access control mechanisms, physical segregation, network segregation, etc.)

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-16: The policy mentions implementing 'measures to protect audit logs' but lacks a specific mandate to prevent modification by individuals or ensure tamper-resistance.

DCF-49.control_description: A password manager is installed on all company-managed devices.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-2: The policy requires users to use an approved password manager if storing passwords, but does not mandate technical installation on all company-managed devices.

DCF-67.control_description: Authentication to systems requires the use of multi-factor authentication.

llm_decision.evidence_quote: MFA must be enabled for any and all systems that provide the option for Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)

gaps_identified.description: Policy limits MFA requirement to systems that natively provide the option, rather than mandating MFA for all system authentication.

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial. The policy mandates technical enablement of MFA, but restricts the scope to systems where the option is available.

DCF-555.control_description: Privacy by design has been implemented into the design and architecture of The Organization's IT systems and business practices.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-17: The policy mandates specific UI prohibitions (dark patterns) under a Privacy by Design header, but this narrow mandate does not satisfy the broad requirement to implement privacy by design across all IT systems and business practices.

DCF-551.control_name: Specific Requirements for Data Subject Notices
DCF-551.control_description: The Organization's notices to data subjects about their rights are easy to read and understandable, be clear and conspicuous, and readily accessible to data subjects with disabilities.

llm_decision.evidence_quote: Data subjects will receive proper notice that their personal information will be collected or processed.

gaps_identified.description: The policy fails to mandate that notices must be readily accessible to data subjects with disabilities.

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial match. While the policy mandates clear and conspicuous notices (Page 2, 3), it lacks the specific mandatory qualifier regarding accessibility for individuals with disabilities (G-10).

DCF-655.control_description: The Organization has implemented a procedure for protection against systems tampering.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-17: Policy mandates a state of protection against tampering for surveillance systems (page 4) but does not establish formal tamper protection procedures for systems.

DCF-836.control_description: The Organization conducts periodic physical facility reviews to identify vulnerabilities and weaknesses in controls (e.g., physical access controls, environmental controls, geographic considerations, etc.) as dictated by company policies. Results are documented and incorporated into risk assessments and risk response strategies.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: While the policy mandates periodic reviews for alarm system configurations, it lacks the mandatory qualifier to conduct broad facility reviews that are incorporated into risk response strategies.

DCF-749.control_description: Critical facilities are equipped with a leak detection system to detect water in the event of a flood or leakage.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-1: The policy mandates 'monitoring' for water (page 5), which is an activity that does not satisfy the requirement for a technical leak detection system.

DCF-816.control_description: The Organization has defined, documented, approved, and enforced physical access restrictions associated with initiating changes to system components by authorized individuals.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Evidence provides general physical access restrictions but lacks the mandatory qualifier linking those restrictions to the initiation of changes.

DCF-366.control_name: Physical Access Control Mechanism Periodic Data Review
DCF-366.control_description: Data collected from video cameras and/or access control mechanisms are reviewed and correlated with other entries (e.g., access logs) on a periodic basis and as needed (e.g., upon suspicious physical security activity).

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-16: While the policy mandates the presence of CCTV and logs, it does not mandate the operational periodic review and correlation of that data as required by the control.

DCF-917.control_description: The Organization maintains a list of in-scope physical sites and facilities.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-11: The document contains a placeholder for locations, but does not mandate the administrative activity of maintaining a formal list or inventory of in-scope facilities.

DCF-530.control_description: The Organization provides mechanisms for data subjects to modify or withdraw their consent. The Organization acknowledges, logs, and documents instances of withdrawals of consent.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. No mandate found for mechanisms to withdraw consent or for the logging/documentation of such withdrawals.

DCF-626.control_description: The Organization has defined privacy reports, and maintains and appropriately disseminates those reports.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-15: Policy mandates a 'Risk Assessment Report' which is a different artifact type than the required 'privacy reports'.

DCF-660.control_description: The Organization has defined and approved risk appetite statements, including statements pertaining to cybersecurity risk, that convey expectations about the level of risk the organization is willing to accept in the pursuit of objectives. These statements are reviewed periodically and updated as necessary.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. The Risk Appetite section on page 4 consists entirely of template placeholders ("<VALUE>") which are inadmissible as evidence.

DCF-807.control_description: The Organization has defined specific, measurable, and broadly understandable risk tolerance statements that describe the acceptable deviation from the level set by the organization's risk appetite and business objectives. These statements are reviewed periodically and updated as necessary.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. The Risk Tolerance section on page 4 consists entirely of template placeholders ("<VALUE>") which are inadmissible as evidence.

DCF-869.control_description: Cybersecurity risk management activities and outcomes are included in enterprise risk management processes, and cybersecurity risks are aggregated and managed alongside other enterprise risks (e.g., documented in the enterprise risk register, etc.).

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-4: The policy defines an information security risk management process but does not mandate integration with Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) or an enterprise risk register as required by the control.

DCF-911.control_name: Risk Assessment Conducted after Major Change
DCF-911.control_description: The Organization conducts risk assessments after every major change in the environment.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-9: Control requires event-driven risk assessments triggered by major changes; policy only mandates periodic annual reviews or updates upon risk discovery.

DCF-842.control_description: The Organization has identified and documented measurable cybersecurity risk management objectives as part of strategic planning which are agreed-upon by relevant stakeholders (e.g., senior leadership, etc.)

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-11: The policy contains placeholders for risk appetite levels (<APPETITE LEVEL>) rather than documented objectives. G-13: Mandating that objectives be determined for treatment is a process step, not the identification of strategic objectives.

DCF-185.control_description: The Organization has implemented mechanisms to collect threat information and produce threat intelligence (e.g., commercial cyber threat intelligence tools, security product/vendor intelligence feeds, open source feeds, etc.) in accordance with defined threat intelligence objectives.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-1: The control requires technical mechanisms to collect and produce threat intelligence, whereas the policy describes an administrative threat assessment process in Appendix A.

DCF-870.control_name: Integrated Cybersecurity Supply Chain Risk Management
DCF-870.control_description: Cybersecurity supply chain risk management activities and outcomes are included in enterprise risk management processes, and cybersecurity supply chain risks are aggregated and managed alongside other enterprise risks (e.g., documented in the enterprise risk register, etc.).

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-17: While the policy includes external services in the asset inventory for general risk assessment, it does not establish an integrated Cybersecurity Supply Chain Risk Management (C-SCRM) program.

DCF-843.control_description: The Organization has defined key risk indicators (KRIs) to identify potential risks in the organization including likelihood and potential impact. The KRI metrics are monitored, reviewed, and reported to senior leadership periodically to inform strategic planning.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-4: Topic overlaps (risk scoring), but policy defines methodology (impact/likelihood) rather than mandating Key Risk Indicators (KRIs).

DCF-874.control_description: The Organization submits a report of its risk management framework review to the appropriate authorities in the proper format, upon completion of its review.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Policy mandates documentation of reviews but lacks the qualifier of submitting that report to 'appropriate authorities'.

DCF-798.control_description: The Organization performs an evaluation of risk (including supply chain risk) of unauthorized disclosure resulting from the processing, storage, or transmission of controlled unclassified information (CUI), either as a separate evaluation or as part of the overall organizational risk assessment. The evaluation is performed in accordance with the company's risk assessment methodology and updated periodically.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: The policy is a general risk assessment framework and lacks the mandatory qualifier for Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI) evaluation.

DCF-172.control_description: The Organization has a defined change management process for the organization, business processes, and information processing facilities and systems that affect information security.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-17: Policy references following a change control standard for code, which is a component/input, but does not define the organizational change management process itself.

DCF-4.control_description: The Organization uses a version control system to manage source code, change documentation and tracking, release labeling, and other change management tasks. Access to the version control system is restricted to authorized personnel.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-16: The policy mentions 'branch protection settings' (page 4) but does not mandate the establishment or restricted use of a version control system itself.

DCF-5.control_description: Changes are peer-reviewed and approved prior to deployment by an individual different from the developer to maintain segregation of duties. Review requirements are enforced through automated mechanisms such as branch protection settings in the production code repository.

llm_decision.evidence_quote: Code changes are reviewed by individuals other than the originating code author and by individuals who are knowledgeable in code review techniques and secure coding practices.

gaps_identified.description: The requirement for automated enforcement is qualified by 'where possible' and 'should' on page 4, weakening the technical mandate.

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial. The policy mandates peer review by a different individual (Page 3), but the technical enforcement via automated mechanisms (Page 4) is weakened by 'should' and 'where possible' language.

DCF-7.control_description: Pre-production environments (e.g., development, testing, etc.) are separated from production environments and the separation is enforced with access controls.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-2: The primary technical requirement on page 4 uses non-binding 'should' language, which fails IR-5's restriction on list items. Additionally, the personnel separation mandate on page 3 is an administrative control, creating a G-1 mismatch with this technical control.

DCF-155.control_description: Changes are tested in an environment separate from production prior to deployment in accordance with the nature of the change. Documented evidence of testing criteria and testing results is retained.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: While the policy mandates testing phases and environment separation, it fails to require the retention of documented evidence of testing criteria and results.

DCF-156.control_description: Change releases are approved by authorized personnel prior to deployment to production.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. Soft blocker: The requirement for human approval by an authorized owner (Page 4) uses non-binding language ('should'), and the binding reference to a 'change control standard' (Page 3) lacks explicit approval requirements per G-12.

DCF-926.control_description: The Organization performs output validation during system development that includes plausibility checks, reconciliation control counts, sufficient information for a reader, procedures for responding to validation tests, responsibilities of personnel, and automated log of activities in the data output validation process.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: While 'edit checks' are mentioned on page 4, the policy lacks specific required qualifiers such as reconciliation counts and automated logs of validation activities.

DCF-134.control_name: 3rd Parties and Vendors Given Instructions on Breach Reporting
DCF-134.control_description: The Organization provides vendors and third parties with information on how to report breaches to The Organization.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-17: Control requires providing reporting instructions to vendors; evidence mandates establishing legal responsibilities and timing in contracts, which is a component but not the instruction itself.

DCF-919.control_description: The Organization maintains documented agreements for e-commerce arrangements, including agreed terms of trading and details of authorization.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-4: General vendor management requirements do not specifically address the domain of e-commerce arrangements or terms of trading.

DCF-849.control_description: The Organization has defined and documented exit strategies for terminating or transitioning supplier relationships.

llm_decision.evidence_quote: Collaborative efforts and responsibilities with cloud service providers will be defined, with consideration given to the following aspects: ... How to change or stop the use of cloud services including exit strategies for cloud services.
llm_decision.location_reference: Page 4, Collaborative efforts and responsibilities with cloud service providers

gaps_identified.description: The mandate to define exit strategies is explicitly limited to Cloud Service Providers, not all IT vendors/suppliers.

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial. scope_gap: Policy mandates defining exit strategies only within the specific context of cloud service providers, missing broader vendor scope.

DCF-762.control_description: Changes to the provision of services by vendors, including expansions of services and supplier changes, require review and due diligence activities and are authorized by management. Documentation of the due diligence activities and authorization is retained.

llm_decision.evidence_quote: Changes to the provision of services by vendors, including maintaining and improving existing information security policies, procedures and controls, will be managed, taking account of business information criticality, systems and processes involved and re-assessment of risks.

gaps_identified.description: The policy mandates risk re-assessment for changes but does not explicitly require management authorization.

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial. Policy mandates management of changes and risk re-assessment but fails to require management authorization or explicit record retention for the change process.

DCF-868.control_name: Cybersecurity Supply Chain Risk Management Program
DCF-868.control_description: The Organization has defined and documented a cybersecurity supply chain risk management program, including a plan (with milestones), policies, and procedures that guide implementation and improvement of the program.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-17: This policy establishes requirements for vendor management but lacks the specific 'plan (with milestones)' and 'procedures' components of the required supply chain program.

DCF-784.control_description: The Organization checks software components and libraries for policy and license compliance, security risks, and supported versions (e.g. using software composition analysis (SCA) tools in development pipeline, etc.). If vulnerabilities in these software components or libraries are identified, fixes are implemented in accordance with the company's vulnerability management policies.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-4: The policy mandates general vulnerability scanning but does not explicitly require software composition analysis (SCA) or library/dependency checking.

DCF-297.control_description: The Organization has implemented a formal patch management process where critical patches/updates (as identified per the entity's vulnerability risk analysis) are installed within one month of release. All other applicable security patches/updates are installed within the timeframe established by the entity per the risk analysis and company policies and procedures.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: The policy fails to mention a formal patch management process or the specific numeric timeframe (one month) for installing critical patches.

DCF-677.control_description: The Organization has implemented a software update management process where critical patches and application updates are installed for all authorized software within priority SLAs established in company policies.

llm_decision.evidence_quote: The purpose of this policy is to outline the requirements for (1) all product systems to be scanned for vulnerabilities at least annually, and (2) all vulnerability findings to be reported, tagged, and tracked to resolution in accordance with the SLAs defined herein.

gaps_identified.description: Policy mandates patching and resolution only for security vulnerabilities, not general software and application updates.

llm_decision.reasoning: Partial. scope_gap: The policy establishes a remediation process and SLAs for vulnerability findings, but does not cover a general software update management process for all authorized software.

DCF-19.control_description: An external penetration test of production environments is performed by an independent third party periodically or after any significant infrastructure or application changes. Results are reviewed by management and vulnerabilities are tracked to resolution in accordance with company policies.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Policy lacks required qualifiers for mandatory third-party performance (it allows internal) and trigger after infrastructure changes.

DCF-456.control_description: All critical or high vulnerabilities identified are addressed immediately and a subsequent scan is performed to validate resolution. All other applicable vulnerabilities are addressed based on the company's evaluation of risk per documented policies and procedures and rescans are conducted as needed to confirm resolution.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: The policy lacks the 'immediately' qualifier for critical/high vulnerabilities and remediation instructions are written using non-binding 'should' language.

DCF-875.control_description: An advanced and threat-lead penetration test (TLPT) on critical systems is conducted by an accredited, reputable, and capable independent third party.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Policy lacks required qualifiers (threat-lead, accredited status) and permits internal testers, violating the requirement for an independent third party.

DCF-465.control_description: The Organization conducts external penetration tests at least once every 12 months or after any significant infrastructure or application upgrade or change per the company's defined methodology. Testing is performed by a qualified internal resource or qualified external third party and organizational independence of the tester is maintained.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-10: Policy fails to mandate the 12-month frequency or the 'after significant change' trigger required by the control.

DCF-817.control_description: The Organization has implemented automated tools to analyze the security configurations of its cloud environment(s) and continuously monitor for misconfigurations, vulnerabilities, and security risks (e.g., cloud security posture management software, configuration management tools, etc.).

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-4: The policy addresses general vulnerability scanning and malware protection but does not specifically mandate automated monitoring of cloud environment configurations.

DCF-903.control_description: The Organization centrally manages enterprise anti-malware software.

llm_decision.reasoning: No match. G-16: The policy mandates deployment and automatic updates of anti-malware but does not explicitly require central management of the software.
